particulars: First EIC voyage. Four ships under Lancaster sailed to Bantam (Java). Captured a rich Portuguese carrack en route. Established first English trading factory in Southeast Asia. Returned with 1,030,000 lbs of pepper.
Accompanied Lancaster's Red Dragon on the first EIC voyage. Smaller vessel that assisted in trading operations at Bantam.
Third EIC voyage under Keeling. Famous for performances of Hamlet and Richard II aboard ship off Sierra Leone in 1607.
Largest English merchant ship of her time at 1,100 tons. Reached Bantam but was damaged and abandoned there in 1613. Caught fire and burned at her moorings. A catastrophic loss for the early EIC.
Sailed to Japan via Bantam. Established the short-lived English trading factory at Hirado, Japan, in 1613. Carried letters from King James I to the Shogun.
Tenth EIC voyage. Best defeated a Portuguese fleet off Surat in November 1612, winning trading rights from the Mughal Emperor Jahangir.
Sailed to the Banda Islands (Spice Islands). Courthope defended Run Island against the Dutch for four years before being killed in 1620. Ship lost.
Early Surat voyage. The EIC was consolidating its position on the Indian west coast during this period.
Voyage during the Anglo-Dutch rivalry period. Tensions with the VOC in the Spice Islands were escalating.
Baffin, the famous Arctic explorer, sailed as master. He would later be killed at the siege of Qeshm Island in 1622.
Voyage during the period when the EIC was establishing Fort St George (Madras) as a major settlement.
One of the first English attempts to trade directly with China. Weddell's fleet clashed with Chinese forts at Canton.
Routine voyage to the Coromandel Coast during the early development of the EIC Madras settlement.
Sailed during the English Civil War period. The EIC maintained operations despite domestic turmoil.
Post-Civil War voyage. The Commonwealth government renewed the EIC charter.
Cromwell's government supported the EIC. This period saw expansion of trade in Indian textiles.
Restoration-era voyage. Charles II granted the EIC new privileges including the right to mint money and command fortresses.
Bombay had been transferred to the EIC by Charles II. Aungier would become governor and develop Bombay as the EIC's western headquarters.

cargo_description: English cloth, metals, and trade goods
particulars: Voyage to the Coromandel Coast during the period of expanding textile trade between India and England.
Sailed during the Third Anglo-Dutch War. EIC ships often required naval escort in wartime.
Period of expanding EIC presence on the Coromandel Coast.
Pitt would later become Governor of Madras and acquire the famous Pitt Diamond (Regent Diamond), now in the Louvre.
Barlow kept one of the most famous maritime journals of the era, covering decades of seafaring life.
Knox had been a prisoner in Ceylon for 19 years. His account inspired parts of Defoe's Robinson Crusoe.
Captain Kidd, originally commissioned as a privateer, turned pirate and was later captured, tried, and hanged in 1701.
Hamilton served in the EIC for decades and wrote 'A New Account of the East Indies', one of the best contemporary descriptions.
War of the Spanish Succession era. EIC ships were vulnerable to French privateers.
Post-Union voyage. The EIC and the rival 'New East India Company' had been merged in 1708.
Period of the South Sea Bubble era. EIC was one of the great chartered companies.
Early direct China trade. The EIC was beginning to import large quantities of tea from Canton.
The EIC's Bombay dockyard was becoming a major shipbuilding center.
The Canton tea trade was rapidly expanding. Tea was becoming Britain's national drink.
Routine voyage during a period of relative peace in India.
Growing tea imports. Parliament granted the EIC a tea monopoly.
First voyage of the Dodington. This ship would later be wrecked.
War of Jenkins' Ear era. Increasing hostility with Spain.
War of the Austrian Succession. French and English EIC forces were beginning to clash in India.
Dupleix and the French were threatening Madras.
Named after Commodore Anson who had circumnavigated the globe.
Pigot would later become Governor of Madras.

cargo_description: military stores, bullion, and gold coins
particulars: Wrecked on Bird Island, Algoa Bay, South Africa, 17 July 1755 during outward voyage. Carried a chest of gold pagodas for the Madras garrison. Wreck found in 1977 by Dave Allen.
Clive sailed to India where he won the Battle of Plassey (1757), establishing British dominance in Bengal.
Post-Plassey era. The EIC was becoming the de facto ruler of Bengal.
Seven Years' War era. EIC and Royal Navy cooperated to take French possessions in India.
Growing tea trade with China.
The EIC received the diwani (tax-collecting rights) of Bengal in 1765.
Expansion of the Bombay marine (EIC's naval force).
First successful voyage of the Royal Captain.
Wrecked near Robben Island, Cape of Good Hope, 25 August 1773 during a severe storm. All crew saved but ship was a total loss.
Tea Act of 1773 gave the EIC a monopoly on tea sales to America, triggering the Boston Tea Party.
American War of Independence era. EIC ships were vulnerable to American and French privateers.
Wrecked 4 August 1782 on the coast of Pondoland, South Africa. The survivors' terrible overland march is one of the most famous shipwreck narratives. Rumoured to carry the Peacock Throne jewels.
Wrecked 6 January 1786 on the cliffs at Seacombe, Isle of Purbeck, Dorset. Captain Pierce, his two daughters, and ~168 others perished. One of the most widely reported shipwrecks of the 18th century.

cargo_description: provisions and supplies for Botany Bay colony
particulars: Struck an iceberg 13 December 1789 south of the Cape of Good Hope. Riou kept the sinking vessel afloat for weeks until rescued. One of the earliest iceberg collisions on record.
Wrecked 20 August 1792 on a reef off the coast of Madagascar. Most passengers and crew survived but endured months stranded before rescue.
Major China Indiaman. The Canton tea trade was at its peak.
French Revolutionary Wars made the voyage hazardous.
First successful voyage of the Arniston.
Wartime China trade. EIC ships often sailed in convoy with naval escort.
Captain John Wordsworth, brother of the poet William Wordsworth. First successful voyage of the Earl of Abergavenny.
Major China Indiaman during the Napoleonic Wars.

cargo_description: English woolens, military stores, and bullion
particulars: Wrecked 5 February 1805 off Weymouth, Dorset, striking the Shambles bank. Captain John Wordsworth and ~260 others drowned. His brother William Wordsworth wrote several poems in his memory. One of the most significant EIC shipwrecks.
Named after the first Governor-General of India.
Large China Indiaman. Growing demand for tea in Britain.
Napoleonic Wars. EIC ships frequently engaged French privateers.
Expansion of the Bombay presidency.
Major China trader during the height of the tea trade.

cargo_description: military stores and passengers (344 soldiers and invalids)
particulars: Wrecked 30 May 1815 near Waenhuiskrans (Arniston), South Africa, during a violent storm. Only 6 of 378 aboard survived. The nearby town was renamed Arniston in memory.
Post-Napoleonic War era. The Canton trade system was firmly established.
Routine India trade during the post-war period.
EIC trade was increasingly challenged by private merchants.

cargo_description: military stores, cargo, and 20 officers with families
particulars: Caught fire 1 March 1825 in the Bay of Biscay. 81 lives lost of 641 aboard. Most passengers rescued by the brig Cambria. Captain Cobb was among the last to leave the burning ship.
The opium trade was becoming increasingly important to EIC finances.
Named after the EIC chairman. Steam was beginning to appear on Indian rivers.
The China tea trade was at its peak. Opium imports to China growing.
Reform era. The EIC's India monopoly was abolished in 1833.
One of the last EIC monopoly China voyages. The China trade monopoly was abolished in 1834.
Post-monopoly era. Private merchants now competed freely.
Named after the Governor-General. Tensions with China over opium trade were escalating.
Iron-hulled steamer that played a decisive role in the First Opium War (1839-1842). First iron warship to round the Cape.
First Opium War era. Hong Kong was ceded to Britain in 1842.
Steam and sail co-existed. The Overland Mail route via Suez was reducing passage times.
Period of railway construction beginning in India.
Industrial goods increasingly replacing traditional exports.
Era of rapid modernization in India.
The Great Exhibition of 1851 showcased Indian goods in London.
Crimean War era. Indian troops were deployed to Crimea.
Indian Rebellion of 1857 was the defining crisis that led to the dissolution of the EIC.
Early Surat trade. Hippon was one of the first EIC agents at Surat.
Pring was a veteran navigator who had explored New England.
Baffin's extensive navigational observations contributed to cartography.
Dutch-English rivalry was intensifying in the Spice Islands.
Weddell was one of the most active early EIC captains.
Methwold became president of the Surat factory.
Early Madras trade. Fort St George under construction.
English Civil War era. Parliament and Royalists both claimed EIC revenues.
Bantam remained an important EIC trading post.
Commonwealth period. Cromwell supported East India trade expansion.
Last years of the Commonwealth. The Restoration was imminent.
Early Restoration period. Charles II was expanding EIC privileges.
Bombay was being developed as a major EIC base.
Madras textile trade expanding rapidly.
Period of expanding calico imports from India.
Tensions with the Mughal Empire increasing.
EIC was fortifying its Indian settlements.
Glorious Revolution era. New charter granted by William III.
Bowrey was a notable chronicler of Asian maritime trade.
Annesley served in the EIC for decades in various capacities.
War of the Spanish Succession era.
Early Canton direct trade.
Queen Anne's reign. EIC and 'New Company' recently merged.
Calcutta was growing as the EIC's eastern headquarters.
Growing Canton tea trade.
Bengal textile exports were enormous.
Macrae had been governor of Madras.
Major China trader. Tea imports approaching 4 million lbs annually.
Post-war China trade resumption.
Named after the EIC fortress in Calcutta.
Seven Years' War. Major reinforcements for India.
Post-war China trade expansion. Treaty of Paris (1763).
Father of the future Earl of Abergavenny captain.
Growing Bengal indigo trade.
American Revolution era. EIC ships required convoy protection.
War period. French fleet under Suffren threatened EIC interests.
Wrecked 26 January 1786 on rocks at Plymouth Sound. All passengers and crew rescued, largely due to the heroism of Sir Edward Pellew (later Lord Exmouth).
Growing tea and silk trade.
Grant would become chairman of the EIC's Court of Directors.
French Revolutionary Wars. Heavy convoy escort required.
Napoleonic Wars. EIC expanding in western India.
Battle of the Nile (1798) secured the eastern Mediterranean.
Brief Peace of Amiens (1802).
Napoleonic Wars resumed after Amiens.
Horsburgh compiled famous hydrographic charts of Asian waters.
Named after the naval hero. Major India trader.
War of 1812 era. American privateers posed a threat.
End of Napoleonic Wars. Post-war trade expansion.
Growing opium trade financing tea purchases.
Expansion of EIC territory in western India.
EIC building 'factories' in Canton.
First Burmese War (1824-1826) era.
Post-war consolidation in India.
Canton system of trade. Foreign merchants confined to factories.
EIC's India monopoly abolished by Charter Act 1833.
Post-Opium War. Treaty of Nanking opened five ports.
Post-treaty trade expansion.
Indian Rebellion of 1857 imminent.
EIC governing India under Crown control since 1858.
EIC winding down as governing entity.
Suez Canal would open in 1869, revolutionizing the route.
Among the final EIC-associated voyages. The Company was formally dissolved on 1 June 1874 by the East India Stock Dividend Redemption Act. End of 274 years of corporate history.
